The following is not directed at anyone in particular, and was not inspired by any one post or event. What is up with people who don't capitalize or use correct punctuation or grammar because "im too lazy" or "its not important" or whatever? Fine, fine, you only don't do it when using online communication. I get that. I'll even grant that maybe you won't slip up when you're typing up a resume, a cover letter or (if you're lucky enough to get the job) an annual report or email to your boss or something like that. To me, that's a good enough reason on its own. I am a creature of habit, and if I misuse it in casual conversation, I'll be more likely to misuse it when it matters. Maybe it doesn't work that way for them. "kewlies" But here's the thing: It's online COMMUNICATION. I.e., by DEFINITION, you're trying to send a message to a reader. Non-capitalization, incorrect punctuation and bad grammar make it HARDER for the reader to receive your communication. I don't WANT to read something written in that way, unless I have a very good reason to. What you have to say probably doesn't qualify. I'd wager most people who read your writing are similar. The bottom line: If what you have to say isn't worth enough of your time to write correctly, it isn't worth my time to read.

My girlfriend bought me a 256 MB Lexar jumpdrive for Christmas, and while I haven't used it a ton, I still think it's pretty cool. After reading all the stuff on Hackaday, I got to thinking. . . That's the actual guts of the jumpdrive. I scanned my room for something about that size. I thought of making a Zippo-drive, attaching it to my watch (it's about the size of the face of my watch...the USB plug would be sticking out to the side, and various other things. I then went in search of a Pez dispenser after reading about the guy who invented and successfully pitched to PEZ an .mp3 player stuffed into a Pez dispenser. So anyway, I pulled out my easter pez dispenser and its two packs of Pez candy. Hmm, I thought. I got to work. Using a pocket knife I heated in a candle, I managed to cut a CD case down into the sizes I needed. I then duct taped the pieces together, resulting in this: That part took the most work. Then I simply carefully unwrapped the Pez candy (it USED to be a removable sleeve with the flavor around the foil pack of candy...that would have been a LOT more handy, thank you very much...now it's all one piece), wrapped the USB drive and taped. The results: It's actually smaller than the size of a pack of Pez candy: two inches long, plus the plug, and about 3/8 of an inch thick. I like it.

POOP. I've just found a large amount of ticket vouchers for a long-defunct arcade. From April 3 of 1999 to November 26 (I apparently went there six weekends during that period, as those are the only dates I have vouchers from), I earned 1421 tickets. And now they're worth nothing. DRAT!

WTF?! (possibly NSFW ads/links...) I defy anyone to look at this for more than 60 seconds without even giggling just a little. (same deal...)

It seems as if IU has finally decided to revoke my mail account and webspace, almost a whole year after I left. Or maybe they're just having problems. I don't know.

Anyhow, anyone have suggestions on free webspace that won't pummel me with ads?

Oh man, this is so cool. I'm writing this post using Ritepen. It's handwriting recognition software for ANY text input area. For example, I'm writing this post right in Semagic without any intervening windows or input areas. One of the coolest things about the software is that regular cursive handwriting works! and that's exactly how I'm writing on my graphics tablet. Another pretty cool thing is that you can write entire phrases at once, just as if you were writing normally. I would estimate about a 75% success rate (and it even handled the percent sign and parenthases just fine!) (and the exclamation point!) at this point, and I only downloaded it about fifteen minutes ago. It is slower than typing, but it's interesting and might just be worth the $20. I'm sure most of you will have no use for this, but if you do have a graphics tablet, you should definitely check this out. I wrote this entire post without touching the keyboard.

Offenders: Roseanne, Family Matters (TWICE!), Boy Meets World, et. al. General Premise: Main characters somehow find themselves in a boxing ring with a pro. Hilarity ensues. Exceptions: Full House (I think), Step by Step (maybe...I seem to remember Mark wrestling someone. Or maybe JT). Elaboration: Family Matters' Wrestling Match episode was the best. Both of them. The one where Steve fights for Laura's honor or somesuch (STEVE, STAY DOWN!), and the one where Eddie and Carl tag team against some "pro wrestlers" (I HATE cops!).

Name a CD you own that no-one else on your friends list does: I'd be willing to bet that a large portion of my CDs are unique to me. Anyone ever heard of Knowdaverbs? Christian rap artist. Yes, really. Luna Halo, anyone? Up With People? I've got local groups too. Also about 8 bajillion compilations, mostly Christian music. Some actual interesting ones: "The Wit & Wisdom of Andy Griffith" (all comedy), "The Other Guys" which is an acapella group from the University of Illinois, "Thank You" by Straight No Chaser (the acapella group of Indiana University), and "Main Street Electrical Parade" from Walt Disney World, which is just the soundtrack to the parade.The song only physically takes up about half of the disc, so the other half is transparent. It's pretty cool. Name a book you own that no-one else on your friends list does: Jeeze, I have no idea. Most of my textbooks you probably don't have. I have M.C. Escher, his life and complete works...Henry Ernest Dudeney's 536 Puzzles & Curious Problems published in 1967? Considering the political bent of most of the people on my friends list...The O'Reilly Factor? Name a movie you own on DVD/VHS/whatever that no-one else on your friends list does: Discounting home movies and movies of events I was in (concerts and whatnot), of which I have a lot...I'm gonna say either Short Circuit or *Batteries not included. Name a place that you have visited that no-one else on your friends list has: Besides my hometown? Any number of the little tiny towns around here, I suppose. I figure someone has to have been to Branson, MO. Hope College in Holland, Michigan? Cooperstown, NY? I need to get out more.

From the "Weird ways to censor movies on TV" file,
You see what happens, Larry? You see what happens when you find a stranger in the alps? Larry, do you see what happens? Do you see what happens when you feed a stranger scrambled eggs?

Firstly, I should say that I'm not entirely sure what made me realize this particular thing at that particular moment. I believe it was that I was looking up the history of eye-black use by athletes for a thread on the SDMB (that's that message board I'm always talking about, for those of you (that one of you?) on my friends list who are (is) unaware). That and the fact that I received a Levenger catalogue in the mail the other day, and have been using my fountain pen more. Odd combination, I know, but stick with me here. Ok, so the thing is, I don't appear to be specializing in anything. I'm not sure if it's a problem or not, but it's just strange to think about. I'm comfortable on a baseball/softball field. As I was looking up the eye-black, I reminisced about my days in little league and chuckled to myself over the thought of a couple friends of mine being in that situation. Would they even know what to do with the eye-black? Where the shortstop plays? The proper way to catch a fly ball? I'm talking fundamentals, people. Runner on first, no outs, pitcher up? Bunt the man over. Lay down a good one too, none of this jabbing at the ball crap. This isn't billiards. I flit back to the Levenger catalogue, I don't know why. Deep earthy tones, leather armchairs that swallow you and your book, gleaming fountain pens with real ink flowing smoothly from the nib onto a textured page. Leatherbound. Academic. Lavish. Makes me think of fall for some reason. Flit back to my job. I know basic principles of design. I know basic principles of journalism. Give me stories and photos and I can throw together a readable and perhaps attractive newspaper page, program for a play, poster, etc. Give me a camera and a subject and I can make a passably artistic photo. Give me a notepad and a pen and I can interview. Flit back to college. Stately. Academic (again). Slow. Archaic. I sing, solo or in a choir. Acapella or not. Latin? Italian? German? Spanish? French? Olde English? Check. I play piano. I explore campus. Flit back to sitting in front of the computer. I can slap together a crude HTML page. I know where to find things. I have access to information and I know how to use it. I've designed Flash animations for various things. Thing of it is, I know how to exist in each of these worlds. I can get along in any or all of them just about as often as I need to. More worlds than this...these are just a sample. I can get by in any of those environments. So what's the problem? I guess the problem is that I'm not entirely comfortable in any of them. Not entirely. I don't quite fit. Something's just a bit off. I go after one for a while, and the part that doesn't fit, the part that's irritating me, the part that is unfulfilling, the part of me that's not getting satisfied, whichever of those things, makes me move on to the next one. And after a while, I do it again. I'd like to find something I'm comfortable with. Some thing, activity, place, that's mine. Completely. Another part of this, and one that I happen to think is pretty selfish but at the same time, normal, is that I'm not the best at anything. I don't mean the best of anyone anywhere, I just mean the best I know. As far as I'm aware, no one ascribes any particular ability or activity particularly to me. I've never heard of anyone in my real life (admittedly I'm limiting the sample considerably there...) thinking "Hm...he really knows _______." or "Maybe I should call him to ask about/see about doing _______." If I was the "go-to" guy for something, I think that would (sort of by definition, if you take my meaning) make me feel as if I had a niche. Anyhow...just something I was thinking about.

Offenders: Full House, Family Matters, Step By Step, (more that I'm sure I'm unaware of). General Premise: EITHER
One main character finds out he's really good at pool, the other main characters get him to play a shark for money, main character's glasses get broken (or they are otherwise not able to play), shark insists on playing, main character's father/grandmother/whatever comes in and makes a trick shot to save the day.
OR
One main character hustles another (in the case of Full House).
Exceptions: I don't think Roseanne had a Pool Hustle episode.

Saved By The Bell: The College Years, the TV Movie, Wedding in Vegas. SO FREAKIN' WEIRD. The whole style is just different. It's so...7th Heaven ish. Kelly has short hair. Not Attractive. It's just weird. That's all there is to it. Like you take your favorite TV show characters and throw them into a completely different situation. Just a generic TV movie, which is essentially what this is. This really makes you realize how much a setting becomes ingrained into a show. Supporting characters. Extras. Standard camera angles. Everything. Just so odd. Bizzaro-saved-by-the-bell. Edit the first: Insanely large car phone? Check. Edit the second: Gilbert Gottfried? Check. Trying to get Zack and Screech to be MALE ESCORTS?! Uh...check.
Updates if I feel like it, as the show progresses.

You wore biker shorts under your skirts and felt stylish. 5. You yearned to be a member of the Baby-Sitters Club and tried to start a club of your own. 6. You owned those little Strawberry Shortcake pals scented dolls 7. You know that "WOAH" comes from Joey on Blossom. 8. Two words: M.C. Hammer 9. If you ever watched "Fraggle Rock." 10. You had plastic streamers on your handle bars. 11. You can sing the entire theme song to "Duck Tales." 12. You remember when it was actually worth getting up early on a Saturday to watch cartoons. 13. You wore a ponytail on the side of your head. 14. You saw the original "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" on the big screen. 15. You got super-excited when it was Oregon Trail day in computer class at school. 16. You played the game "MASH." 17. You wore a Jordache Jean jacket and you were proud of it 18. L.A. Gear Had the shoes. 19. You wanted to change your name to "JEM" in Kindergarten. 20. You remember reading "Tales of a fourth grade nothing" and all the Ramona books. 21. You know the profound meaning of "WAX ON, WAX OFF." 22. You wanted to be a Goonie. 23. You ever wore fluorescent clothing. 24. You can remember what Michael Jackson looked like before his nose fell off. 25. You have pondered why Smurfette was the only female smurf. 26. You took plastic cartoon lunch boxes to school 28. You still get the urge to say "NOT" after (almost) every sentence. 29. You remember Hypercolor T-shirts. 30. Barbie and the Rockers was your favorite band. 31. You thought She-Ra and He-Man should hook up. 32. You thought your childhood friends would never leave because you exchanged friendship bracelets. 33. You owned a pair of jelly sandals. 34. After you saw Pee-Wee's Big Adventure you kept saying "I know you are, but what am I?" 35. You remember "I've fallen and I can't get up!" 36. You remember going to the skating rink before there were inline skates. 37. You ever got seriously injured on a Slip 'n' Slide. 38. You have ever played with a Skip-It. 39. You had or attended a birthday party at McDonald's. 41. You remember Popples. . 42."Don't worry, be happy." 43. You wore like, EIGHT pairs of socks over tights. 44. You wore socks scrunched down. Still do... :^) 45. "Miss MARY MACK MACK MACK, all dressed in BLACK BLACK BLACK" 46. You remember boom boxes vs. CD players. They're still boom boxes .... 47. You remember watching both "Gremlins" movies 48. You knew what it meant to say "Care Bear Stare!" 49. You remember watching Rainbow Brite and My Little Ponies. 50. You thought Doogie Howser was hot. 51. You remember Alf, the lil furry brown alien from Melmac. 52. You remember New Kids on the Block when they were cool. 53. You knew all the characters names and their life stories on "Saved By the Bell," the ORIGINAL class. 54. You know all the words to Bon Jovi - "YOU GIVE LOVE A BAD NAME" 55. You played and or collected "Pogs" 56. You used to pretend that you could transform into a Power Ranger. The italicized ones I remember but don't necessarily agree with. Doogie Howser wasn't hot, but I watched the show a lot.

Setting: High school lunchroom. 1200 or so students, divided into three lunch periods. Two main lunch lines, leading to four or five cashiers. Also a separate snack-bar line, and a pizza line (with their own cashiers). Pop (soda) machines in a separate room nearby.

The normal hot lunch and the "special" for the day costs $1.40. Other items sold separately. Snack bar items are fairly cheap, pizza is $1.00 a slice, I think. In short, a regular, filling lunch should cost no more than $3-4, depending on the particular food.

Policy: The school will not accept $10 bills (or anything greater) for payment. The individual cashiers say they do not receive enough change to make this a possibility.

I don't go there anymore, but my sister does. I've already suggested the next step is to ask the director of food service what the reason for the policy is, but based on the above information, what do you think?

Now this is the story all about how My life got flipped, turned upside down And I'd like to take a minute just sit right there I'll tell you how I became the prince of a town called Bel-Air In West Philadelphia born and raised On the playground where I spent most of my days Chilling out, maxing, relaxing all cool And all shooting some b-ball outside of the school When a couple of guys said "we're up in no good" Started making trouble in my neighbourhood I got in one little fight and my mom got scared And said "you're moving with your aunt and uncle in Bel-Air" I begged and pleaded with her the other day But she packed my suitcase and sent me on my way She gave me a kissin' and she gave me my ticket I put my walkman on and said I might as well kick it First class, yo this is bad, Drinking orange juice out of a champagne glass Is this what the people of Bel-Air livin' like, Hmm this might be alright! I whistled for a cab and when it came near the License plate said "Fresh" and had a dice in the mirror If anything I could say that this cab was rare But I thought now forget it, yo home to Bel-Air I pulled up to a house about seven or eight And I yelled to the cabby "Yo, home smell you later" Looked at my kingdom I was finally there To settle my throne as the prince of Bel-Air
I love the fact that this game translates to digital form. It's addictive though. Be careful. (has sound, but work safe otherwise...)

Ahh, Elimidate. Tonight, the guy had a 29-year-old divorcee, a mid-20s woman who was a surgical resident at a nearby hospital working 100 hours a week (and oh yeah, she had a three-year-old son living in Australia), a 23-year old attractive but quiet woman, and a 22 year old B*tchy shrewish waitress. In the first round, they went white water rafting and he eliminated the Australian woman. Then the weirdness started. The shrewish waitress was taken off in an ambulance for heat stroke while they were having their round-2 picnic. After that, 23-year old attractive woman and 29-year-old divorcee got into it about 29-year-old's age. Then in the third round, the two people and the guy were at a bar. He said he felt gypped, and left to find another woman, asking everyone at the bar. After he brought her back (a 24-year-old middle school teacher), they sort of ganged up on the 29-year-old, who said she was too mature for it all and left. I thought he was going to end up with the 24-year old teacher, but no. That was just odd.
New LJ Layout. Americana-style. Inspired by the movie/musical 1776. More tweaking as necessary. And a plethora of short sentences!

Wow, that "post at least once every day" thing sure worked out well!

Anyhow...

I just sat down to play a game of Madden 2003 on the PS2. I was the 1988 Chicago Bears.

After I ran the opening kickoff back for a touchdown and intercepted a pass on the opposing team's opening drive, running it back for a touchdown, I got to thinking...

83 points and four quarters later, I had held the computer to 0 points and my offense hadn't stepped on the field once. I scored 83 points with my defense and special teams. And that was with 5 minute quarters!

I ran back most of their punts and the opening kickoff for touchdowns, and I intercepted a lot of passes, running those back for touchdowns. With three seconds to go in the game, I picked up a fumble on their five-yard line and ran it in for a touchdown. Whenever I got the ball not in fieldgoal range (and didn't run it back for a touchdown), I punted.

I ended the game with 0 rushing yardage, 0 passing yardage, 0 interceptions thrown (pretty hard to throw an interception when your QB never takes a snap), and 83 points.

That was fun.

Running total of missed posts: 2
Let me introduce you to my room: I've lived in the same room for about 15 years, and I've slept in the same bed for like 10 years. The walls have been painted once. White. The carpet came original with the house (it's the only room in the house with the original carpet). Yep. That's my carpet. It's a good thing I have a Lava Lamp, balances out the carpet. Referring to the diagram above, number A is my waterbed. I enjoy my waterbed, but it takes up an immense amount of space. I wish I had more space so I could have friends hang out in the room. Tradeoffs. B is my dresser, C is my closet (it used to have sliding doors, but I took them off), D is my bookshelf, E is my crappy desk, F is my record player (sitting on two milk crates holding all my records), G is my computer desk which also holds my TV, VCR, and DVDs and videos, H is my keyboard. The first thing you'll probably notice when you walk through the door is the art border around my wall. It's just this little tedious project we did in my first year of art (that I hated and subsequently dropped...). People seem to like it though. This is the top of the West wall, you can see the tops of my bookshelf and computer desk: If you look left (at the north wall), you'll see a mural I did a few years ago on my wall. I asked my mom if I could paint a mural on my wall. She said to draw it out first. She didn't mean on my wall. I didn't know that. This is on my wall, in colored pencil. It's about 7' high and 4' wide, to give you some perspective... (I had to crank up the contrast in Photoshop so it would show up. It's pretty light on the wall.) So you walk to the foot of my bed (the end not at the wall...) and check out the east wall, which has this hanging on the wall above my bed: This thing is about three feet tall and five feet wide. It's chalk. No, I didn't make it myself, but I wish I did. It's currently unframed, because it costs a lot. I might sacrifice one of my checks eventually and get it done. So, you're at the foot of my bed, the next thing you'll probably notice is the record player (F). I've bought most of my records at the annual sale the local public radio station puts on, where it's $1 per album. As you round the bed and head toward the keyboard (H), you'll notice the bulletin board hanging over it. I used to have a desk over there. Well, a few years back, I ordered a catalogue from Crazyshirts. I noticed that one model appeared in each catalogue several times. One very attractive model. So I made a collage: She's purtier up close. Finally, as you turn back toward the door, you'll see the rest of the artwork from that same series, which I hung above my dresser (B). Well, that's about it, I suppose. I hope you enjoyed your tour. Any questions?

What's the last... 1. ...DVD you bought? I bought Breaking Away yesterday morning. 2. ...apology you made? I apologized to my boss last night. When I was typing scores in on Thursday night, I accidentally put "Tonight's Games" instead of "Thursday's Games." Since that paper came out Friday, people were probably confused. Or really impressed. 3. ...nice thing, no matter how small, you did for someone else? Posted a comment in someone's journal saying I still care. 4. ...food item you ate? Mom-Made hamburgers and french fries with tomatoes from the garden at about 1 this morning (after I got home from work). 5. ...spam subject you received? I don't know. I love gmail.

Yeah, so yesterday wasn't really an entry. I'll make it up later.
I've been wanting to buy Breaking Away on DVD for quite some time, and finally, this morning, I did. I watched the beginning of it, then went to class, and just finished it up. The movie is set in Bloomington, Indiana, where I went to school for a year and a half. It follows a group of four boys dealing with life after highschool in a quintessentially college town. To cut the intro short, it's a great movie and I recommend it to anyone. Breaking Away is so true-to-life, it's amazing. One of the things is examines, being true to life, is the disparity between the residents of Bloomington and the college students. Bloomington was settled in 1815, and just five years later, Indiana University was started. The earliest-known limestone quarry in Indiana was opened 15 miles or so away from Bloomington in 1827. Bloomington was very much a boomtown. When the limestone was discovered and demand was high, fueled regionally by the Great Chicago Fire of 1871 and a similar-though-not-so-great fire in Boston a year later. Indiana limestone also won awards at the Philadelphia and New Orleans Centennial Expositions of 1876. Then it really took off. The Indiana Statehouse and Chicago City Hall are just two of the many buildings that employ limestone quarried from southern Indiana. The number of quarries doubled between 1889 and 1895. George Vanderbilt built a complete mill to produce stone for his Biltmore Estate in North Carolina. In the early 20th century, Indiana Limestone was used for more and more buildings, including skyscrapers such as the Empire State Building in NYC and the Tribune Tower in Chicago. Then business fell off. The Great Depression, WWII, all these factors contributed to the slowdown. 21% of the current buildings on Indiana University's campus (most built from limestone) were built before 1940. Taking advantage of the of the available labor, many factories moved to Bloomington in the 1940s and 50s, including RCA. In the 1960s, the University experienced another boom, and a second (or sometimes third) generation of men went back into the quarries. During the 1960s, 24 buildings were erected on IU's Bloomington campus. During the 1970s, production fell off again. Only five buildings were constructed on IU's campus, and the energy crisis and economy staved off construction in many other places. Many of the men whose fathers had worked the quarries in the 30s and 40s, and who themselves did the backbreaking job through the hard times of the 50s and the boom of the 60s, had established households and children before they were laid off when this recession hit. Breaking Away features a group of 19-year-old friends whose fathers had worked the quarries before being laid off. Raymond Stollar (the main character's father) now makes his living as a used car salesman. The father of Mike (played by Dennis Quaid) is a police officer in town. I don't remember what the other two main characters' fathers do. Anyhow, during a poignant and touching walk through campus with his son David (the main character), Raymond says:
I cut the stone for this building. I was one fine stonecutter. Mike's dad, Cyril's, Moocher's. All of us. Thing of it was, I loved it. I was young and slim and strong, I was damn proud of my work. And the buildings went up. When they were finished, the damndest thing happened. It was like the buildings was too good for us. Nobody told us that. Just...felt uncomfotable, that's all. Even now I'd like to be able to stroll through campus, look at the limestone, but I just feel out of place. You guys still go swimming in the quarries? David: Yeah. So the only thing you got to show for my twenty years of work is the holes we left behind. David: I don't mind. I do.

I found this blog entry linked in the LJ of someone on the friends page of one of my friends (doesn't everyone do that?). I think it's a good idea. So, in recognition of the fact that I don't post very often, and when I DO post, it's very nearly always depressing, I hereby declare this the opening of my official Thirty Days of Blog. At least one post every day, and I'll try to be upbeat, or at least not Strong Sad squared. And by "day" I mean from the time I wake up to the time I fall asleep, so 1 a.m. posts will probably count for the day before. Or something.

It doesn't (have to) cost you any money, just a bit of time and a bit of spam (but hey, you're getting another email address, what do you care if you're getting spam?). Wired says this thing's legit. Ok, so about an hour ago I was thinking that I wanted some caramel corn. Hot, freshly popped caramel corn, not Cracker Jack or anything like that. I remembered having some at a friend's house, a kind where you popped the corn, then put a slab of caramel on it, which then melted as you tossed the corn to coat it. So I drove to the 24-hour store. Well, they don't sell that kind (that I saw) anymore, but PopSecret has a kind where the caramel is included in the bag, and you dump the whole thing out and mix it up after it's popped. So I bought it, came home, popped it, and ate it. It's pretty good. As I was eating it, I decided to look it up online to show people I was talking to in chat. I literally had a mouthful of it as I came across this page. :eek::

I have discovered a whole new level of job suckage. So I've been painting stuff. Now I'm getting down to painting the last stuff I have to paint. Unfortunately there are lots of them, and it's going to be frustrating as all getout. Why, you ask? (or not.) This is a representation of some of the racks in the warehouse I'm painting. To give you a sense of scale, they're probably 20-25 feet tall, there's probably 4 feet or so between them, and the aisles vary in length from long to very long. See the little yellow rails at the bottom? Yeah, I paint those. They're 4-5 inches tall and run around each rack. I (thankfully) only have to paint the ends, and about 10 feet into each aisle. I put down two strips of wide masking tape, paint with a roller, move on, and come back to do a second coat a while later. Now, all this wouldn't be so bad. But... This is a working warehouse. By that, I mean that I work when they work. Unfortunately, in this case, that means that they need stuff off those racks. While I'm painting those rails. They use lift trucks to get it. The lift trucks are designed to nudge up against the rails (so they don't bash up against the racks, so they line up correctly in the aisles, etc.) Again, the rails and racks. The yellow thing in the middle is (supposed to be) a lift truck. They have these little black wheels on the side that are designed to nudge the rails in case the operator can't get it to go right down the middle of the aisle. And they scrape off the paint, if it's not COMPLETELY dry. And it takes at least an hour to completely dry. And we have eight or so lift trucks buzzing around all the time, so the chances of them needing to get down that particular aisle within an hour or so after I've painted it is quite good. I'm literally in the next aisle over when I see a truck go down the one I've just painted, bouncing up against one rail, then the other. I'm not faulting the truck drivers, they're just doing their job, and I'm sure it's nearly impossible to go down the aisle without touching either side (they have maybe an inch of clearance on either side if they're perfectly centered). I've told my boss that it seems almost futile, that I barely make any progress until the very end of the evening (when the workload lightens), and that they tear up the rails quicker than I can paint them. He said, "Well, there's not a lot we can do..." It's like I'm sitting at a desk furiously writing a report, and as soon as I'm done with one sheet and onto the next, someone takes the full sheet and rips it into tiny pieces right in front of my face. Over and over again. The next few weeks are going to be immensely frustrating.

20 questions to a better job Your job's score is 56. The job, not so good. It could be worse, but quite frankly so could a lot of things, and it might interest you to note that the phrase "it could be worse" has not once in the history of man made anyone feel better about their current situation. In fact, if popular media serve as any indicator, all that uttering the phrase aloud ensures that it will start raining on hapless protagonists in the second or third act. One wonders why it hasn't been employed against the perils of famine. Still, it could be worse. Forensic pathology leaps to mind. CSI it ain't.

Your score as a human being is 82.45. You are close to ideal. So close, and yet so far. Amusing, really, to watch someone squirm so close to the vaunted ranks of perfection and still remain so very, very ordinary. It is all one can do to keep one's ingratiating smile from polluting one's perfect face. Actually, one recommends you take the quiz again and lie a little. 20 questions to being a better person

One of those movie ideas I just had:

I want to rig up my car (or a car) with a bunch of video cameras (top looking forward, top looking back, looking out the left and right windows, looking at me and each of the passengers, couple on the sides, etc.), load up the car with a few of my more entertaining acquaintences, and road trip. Route 66, possibly.

All the cameras would be rolling all the time, capturing all the conversation (some possibly scripted, but improv, I'm sure, as well). We'd have a few loose cameras for stopping at gas stations and restaurants and roadside attractions. Kickin' soundtrack, of course. Heck, that could be a minor "plot" point. I keep changing the radio to classical, and the other guys change it back. Or we talk about how we're going to pick the music, and decide that the driver gets first choice, and from that point, you can identify the driver by the background music. I don't know.

Then I edit. We'd have the 1.5-2 hour version for the theater, of course, but the DVD is where things get interesting. I envision several different choices for the movie: a half-hour version, an hour long version, two hours, and so on. I'd edit them all, and they could all probably be different. Probably have an option where you could watch the entire trip in realtime too. That might have to be a separate disc.

Everytime I've been on a longish trip (more than an hour) with one or two other people, we always come up with at least a half hour of some of the most funny things I've ever heard. That's not counting what would be scripted, or any roadside stops.

I think it's doable. Maybe it's been done.

Is it just me, or was the Video Yearbook episode of Saved By The Bell completely ridiculous? I mean, some of the episodes DID have halfway plausible plotlines, but this? Firstly, it was on video. Who wants to hear about EVERY SINGLE STUDENT at their highschool every time they want to browse through their yearbook? Secondly, assuming only a ten-second spot per student, if you've got 1200 students, that's over three hours. And that doesn't count any coverage of sports, extra curricular activities, or other things. I could see something like this being done with DVD today, and I think it could be very cool, if done well. Now, my school did do a senior video, which was cool, but it was just candid shots of seniors around school, sports, extra curricular stuff, various other things, all overlayed with the popular music of the day. Only lasted about a half hour, wasn't meant to be comprehensive, but "highlights." Also, Screech selling spaghetti sauce (how's that for alliteration)? The health department would have been ALL OVER his ass. EDIT: Though Kelly in leather and blue jeans is pretty hot. EDIT the second: Kelly is a maroon. "Why don't we do a rap version of Snow White for the school play?"
Iraq is apparently sovereign now. Cool beans. link

Guy digs a hole, kills a snake, then eats it Pretty hilarious. The snake part is kinda gross. also Park your trailer! This is actually quite fun. You have to get the trailer into the pink area, with the car relatively straight in front of it. I did it in 58 seconds. EDIT: That was my second try. On my third, I did it in 23 seconds. Finally (or not) Check out the new Discovery Channel commercials. Hilarious.

My local public radio (and television) station, WILL, held their annual "Vintage Vinyl" sale today. Every year, they rent out a (large) room in a not-very-popular mall (there's an old one and a new one, and this one's the old one). They fill the place with THOUSANDS of old LPs, cassettes, laserdiscs, and some CDs as well, all sorted by genre, then artist. They also have hundreds of pieces of vintage audio equipment for sale, from belt-drive turntables to top of the line (for the 1970s) speakers. Prices are INSANE. The equipment fetches decent prices, of course, since it's not terribly common, but LPs are a dollar. $1. Even Boxed Sets. There are a few higher priced ones, but those make up less than 1% of all the LPs they have, and probably more like .1%. For instance, this year, they had nearly complete collections of Frank Zappa material and Etta James material. Firstly, when I got there ten minutes before the thing opened, the line was stretched all the way around the building. Everyone rushed in and gravitated toward their favorite genre. I went for Comedy. I spent $20 on LPs. For that, I bought:
  • FIVE Bill Cosby albums, including "Bill Cosby is a Very Funny Fellow Right!" which was is first album, produced by Allen Sherman. Also got "Why is there Air?" which was his third album. Last year, I picked up "Revenge," "Wonderfullness," and "I started out as a child..." which complete his five-album run on the Warner Brothers label. (the other three I bought this year are from later in his career).
  • FOUR Tom Lehrer albums, "An Evening Wasted with Tom Lehrer," "That Was the Year That Was," "More of Tom Lehrer" (which is just a re-recording of "An Evening Wasted" done in the studio instead of live...), and "Songs By Tom Lehrer." Basically, I now have every song Tom Lehrer ever recorded, save a few.
  • A double-album of Woody Allen, "The Nightclub Years: 1964-1968. "In 1964 he recorded his first album live at Mr. Kelly's in Chicago. The following year he recorded a second album at The Shadows, a small cabaret in Washington, D.C. Finally, in 1968, he recorded his third album in concert at Eugene's in San Francisco. . . .United Artists, believing these albums to be important milestones in American comedy, purchased the three masters and after reducing them to two discs (with very few deletions), is re-issuing them so that the world wide following Woody Allen has built up . . .can have an opportunity to hear him as he was in his developing years..."
  • "The Best of Spike Jones", and "The Best of Spike Jones Vol. 2," which include such hilarity as "My Old Flame," "Der Fuehrer's Face," the William Tell Overture ("aaaaaaand Beetlebaum...."), and "Yes, we have no bananas."
  • Two P.D.Q. Bach albums, "P.D.Q. Bach On the Air," including "New Horizons in Music Appreciation," which is a "play-by-play" of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, and "Portrait of P.D.Q. Bach, " including his "Consort of Choral Christmas Carols." Hilarious. Professor Peter Schickele, the guy who "discovered" PDQ, has a show distributed on NPR, Schickele Mix.
  • Bob & Doug McKenzie's "Great White North." Rick Moranis and Dave Thomas (not the Wendy's guy...) are like hilarious, eh? Don't be a hoser, just go get yourself a copy of this album today, like if you can even find it, eh. This also included a single sheet to order Bob & Doug stuff from them (T-shirts or toques for $7!).
  • A SEALED copy of "Shel Silverstein Songs and Stories," including "Father of a Boy Named Sue," "Someone Ate the Baby," and "The Smoke-Off," (which definitely didn't make it into any of his children's poetry books...). I don't know whether to open it or not!!! I'd like to listen to it, and rip it to the computer (so as not to have to worry about scratching the record), but I COULD sell it, and it would probably fetch more wrapped than not.
  • Other than comedy, I love showtunes. I picked up two different copies of the Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat soundtrack. One touts itself as the "first recording of the complete work," and was recorded in England in 1973. I actually had a copy of this before, but the sun ruined it. Hey, everyone does it once, right? The second recording is the Original Broadway Cast Recording, and was recorded in New York City in 1982.
  • Finally, I got a boxed set containing ELEVEN LPs (for $1, remember) of the "120 greatest Broadway songs of all time." This includes a guidebook, which contains commentary on each song. Can't find a year on it, but it includes "Give My Regards to Broadway," from the musical "Little Johnny Jones" (1904!) to songs from The Roar of the Greasepaint -- The Smell of the Crowd (1965). These aren't the original broadway casts, but rearrangements and orchestrations, but they'll help round out my (sparse) collection with some of the essentials.
So, 30 LPs for $20. Correction: 30 GREAT LPs for $20. I love public radio.

Notice: If a person has a job which consists entirely of painting things, it's pretty safe to assume he or she does not find "Missed a spot!" funny anymore. Also please note that, as long as he or she has a brush or roller in his/her hand, there is no answer to the question "Done yet?" more satisfactory than forcefully placing the brush or roller into a random orfice of the asker's body.

Meeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeem. Take your LJ username and replace each letter with the corresponding number (A=1, B=2, etc...). - mr_funny_man (what's an underscore? 0? Wildcard?) = 13+18+0+6+21+14+14+25+0+13+1+14. Add all of the numbers together to create a kind of super number. - 139 (if I did my math correctly) Make a note of the first digit of this number, then add the digits of the number together. - First digit = 1. Digits added together = 13 Find the post of this last number in your LJ. - Post 13 Take the digit you noted in step 3, and count that many words into the post. - "Well" Use the resulting word in a Google Image Search, and select a picture from the first page. - Post the results for us all to see!
